Situation1: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Situation2: Multiple ID types are acceptable, and spare cards can still be fetched later in the day.
Story: The phone pressed against my ear, I listened as Mrs. Carter, a long-time customer, unleashed her frustration about the new offer I was supposed to promote. “How do I know this isn’t a scam?” she demanded, her voice sharp. My manager’s words echoed in my mind: handle objections, keep them on the line, don’t let them hang up angry. I tried to explain, my script faltering as she fired off questions, each one more suspicious than the last. At the same time, my phone buzzed with a reminder: “Don’t forget your ID for voting today.” I glanced at my wallet—my driver’s license was missing, but I had a passport card at home. I could fetch it later, but the polling station closed early. My heart pounded. I needed to reassure Mrs. Carter, but I also needed to make sure I could vote. The pressure from both sides squeezed me, my voice trembling as I tried to juggle the demands—be the patient telemarketer, be the responsible voter. I felt torn, caught between the expectations of my job and my duty as a citizen, unsure which role to serve first.
